A new German movie about Adolph Hitler opened this week and it's a comedy.
Mein Führer"" is the first mainstream German film to make fun of the Nazi leader.
While laughing at Hitler has been a successful form of comedy in the United States and Great Britain, it's been unusual - if not outright taboo - in Germany.
NPR's Emily Harris reports from Berlin that discussions about the film in Hitler's homeland might outlast its popularity.
Here's the basic plot of ""Mein Führer: The Truly Truest Truth About Adolf Hitler."" It's December 1944.
Germany has all but lost World War II and Hitler is depressed and unable to do anything.
His propaganda minister organizes a major New Year's Day speech for the Führer to rally the nation, and pulls a Jewish actor out of a concentration camp to coach Hitler back to his former glory.
Hitler is played by a beloved German comedian, and his Jewish coach by a well-respected actor.

On opening night at least one audience in Berlin chuckles when the acting coach - also named Adolf, last name Grünbaum, middle name Israel - dressed Hitler in a track suit and made him do deep breathing exercises.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of movie, ""Mein Führer: The Truly Truest Truth About Adolf Hitler"")
They laughed again when Grünbaum punched Hitler and knocked him out.

(Soundbite of laughter)
The film portrays Hitler as an impotent man who plays with battleships in the bathtub and wets his bed.
Most critics have not been amused.
It was not funny at all.
Claudius Seidl writes for the Sunday (unintelligible) newspaper.
He has two main problems with the movie.
One, it makes Hitler seem harmless.
And two, for an intended comedy, it doesn't go far enough.

A Hitler comedy without jokes, without absurdity, without brutality, a comedy which doesn't notice that the aim of a comedy is not to make things harmless, but to make us laugh about the monstrous things because we don't have any other chance to laugh.
The film's suggests Hitler became a brutal dictator because he was mistreated as a child.

Levy is Jewish and was born in Switzerland, where his mother lived after fleeing Hitler's Third Reich.
For me, as a Jewish person who lives here in Berlin, I needed a new approach.
